messageBody:
On Wednesday 21 September 2005 16:39, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Chris Dollin wrote:
> > It occurs to me that I have no idea what Java does when it reads
> > from files which are not just bytestreams (ie, are record-structured).
> > Oh well, another TODO for my copious free time.
>
> You're dating yourself. :-) There's no such thing as a record structured
> file on a modern OS; or rather there's no standard thing.

It is sufficient if such things exist, "standard" or not, on
platforms supporting Java, "modern" or not.

> File are
> sequences of bytes, nothing more. It's completely up to the program
> reading the file how to interpret it, including how to find any record
> boundaries in that file.

It's a nice philosophy. Hey, it's so nice I'm happy with it; but I
remember the days when there /were/ filing systems with special
formats, and OS calls to read those formats and do the grunt work
for you, and what a total and absolute pain it was when "it's a
byte stream" got in the way of "and this is the data".

[Editing object files on RSX-11M was, I think, the activity that
provoked particular horror. "Editing" means "writing a program
to do systematic renaming of compiler-genrated identifiers".]

I didn't think those days had gone away. Delight me.

> Java does exactly what the program tells it to do.

The program says "read [or write] the next K bytes down this
stream". If "this stream" happened to be connected to a record-
oriented file, Java should do exactly what the program says -
which is to invoke the filing-system call appropriate to writing
to that file, I would have thought, not just splattering the
bytes randomly into the file's blocks.

One can certainly take the view that Java programs just cannot
handle such files on such filing systems. One may also scratch
one's head about whether this is a good thing.

> Applications should not be written to local conventions. Your program
> should generate the same output whether it runs on a Mac, Windows, Unix,
> or something else. It rally doesn't matter whether you pick \n, \r, or
> \r\n; but pick one and be done with it. Don't change it just because the
> platform changed. Otherwise you get into the trouble that started this
> whole thread, where a program that works on one system fails for no
> apparent reason on another.

If there are applications on those platforms that /demand/ the
platform-local format - they need not be Java applications, nor
need they be "reasonable text editors" - then wilfully getting
in their way doesn't seem to me to be good policy.

[Which is why Jena's RDF/XML writer uses line.separator at a
critical point; we had been generating RDF/XML that some
application running on Windows Did Not Like. Having the user
change it to a Modern Application wasn't an option.]

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
The software engineer's song: "who knows where the time goes".
